comment: This is always so hard for me. I don’t know if I’ve ever made it the full breath hold for even a minute. I don’t feel the peace and calm you all describe. I feel panic and anxiety. It makes me feel like I’m going to die. What am I doing wrong?
replies: ['How’s it going buddy. I’m sure you might get different responses but I think they might all suggest that’s perfectly ok. I don’t want to undermine how scary it is because believe me. ITS TERRIFYING. My wife is a therapist, and she has taught me many breathing techniques…… none of them make my heart race make me feel like I’m gonna pass out or make my fingers and toes tingle like the wim hof breathing method. So the first time I did it I had that exact feeling. I thought we were going to do something calming and then I had to do these crazy breaths for 30 reps. If I had two pieces of real advice, they would be this. 1 don’t be afraid to breathe a little bit slower than he suggests. Usually I’ll do 25 to 27 breaths instead of 30. It just takes me a little longer to fully breathe in and then do a relaxing, exhale than he does, so I feel rushed and I start to panic breath. I decided it would probably be better for me to just do 25 more calm breaths than 30 panicked ones. So don’t be afraid to go at your own pace if you will. And #2 when you get to the final breath hold, try and only focus on two things if you can. All the feelings you have in your body and his voice. He tells you that if your heart is racing and if your body temperature is changing if your fingers and toes are tingling, that that’s ok. I struggle with anxiety and this helps me be able to have a better mind-body connection and overtime. You start to feel less anxious about how your body is reacting to these crazy breath workouts. There is also a Wim Hof breathing technique for beginners where she does 30 seconds than a minute than a minute and a half. Maybe try the 32nd one a few times and build your way up. Hope any of this will help you get a little more enjoyment out of this. Good luck all the love all the power. 👍', '@@cocodadon7245 thank you so much for this. I was starting to feel like I was the only one struggling based on how many people are raving about their calm feelings and success here in the comments. I usually feel pretty good and when I’m done but when it’s happening I just can’t get myself to calm down. I’ll definitely try your tip to slow my breathing down cause I struggle to keep up with him too. Thanks again!', '@@91agraham  awesome!! Glad I could help. Yeah it’s definitely hard balance of stress and peace lol. I feel the same way because he says in with peace and out with stress. But I always feel like my inhales are super stressful so even I don’t 100% feel like I’m doing it right. I’m getting there tho!', 'Never force the breath hold. If you need to breathe then breathe. The only thing you need to focus on is taking deep full breaths and with time the breath hold will come naturally. Not by force ❤', '@@Sandalwoodrk thank you. I try to never force it']

Can he do this without losing his intelligence perhaps ? It's certainly an alternative niche.

Where some try to use their brain. Some have their heads bashed and don't have the option to be intelligent.  Instead. They can be stupid. But be respected for their physical abilities. 

As in not using their brain. Oxygen is not needed for the brain only movements. Drilled into zombie like being .

Perhaps The Zombie does not want to think. They have shut down their brain to cope with grief or some incident. 

Yet. The Prisoner perhaps is tortured by repeated ordeals. Requiring high intelligence.  Like an exam and then. Also athletic performance. 

However it's going to be dangerous  . Particularly for people. 

Who's minds are alive. A fool can easily do this . But what if an intelligent person with a large brain. Tried to shut down their brain ?

Maybe. The mind would start to die in places ?

In suffered a lack of stimulation.  Similar to that of a Prisoner. Being forced into solitary confinement without much mental stimulation. 

Their brain might inevitably suffer. Short term. Possibly long term damage. Not a result of Scientific study.

Actually. A guess. Using common sense. But in using common sense . There might be protection from a life threatening disease. 

Idiocy. Idiots may survive . But depend on others for their care. And certainly for an income and food .

Maybe that kid. Who came last in sports was an intelligent person ? Unwilling to channel oxygen from the brain to the muscles.

Equally. The athlete might refuse to use the brain and rely on drills and routine.

The athlete is confused by a new challenge. 

Like the brainy person. Shys away from Boxing and Rugby. Or long distance running as well perhaps  ."]

comment: Starting Day 2 with positivity ❤
Gratitude!
Man, my fingers and toes felt like they were vibrating like beaker!!

I have struggled with major depressive disorder, adhd, and autism all of my life. These conditions usually have me bed ridden and suicidal on a regular basis. Today, I was suffering with a particularly strong bout of depression, overstimulation, and hopelessness when I decided I would try to do this breathing method and take a cold shower. Before I did it, I was feeling tired, hateful toward myself, and overwhelmed with life in general. After this exercise was over, tears started falling out of my eyes and I began to feel real emotions for the first time in a while. It’s almost as if those tears were stuck behind a dam of sorrow and fear, begging to be let out. Once I did this exercise, the dam broke and it felt wonderful. Thank you so much for creating this video and this technique ❤

comment: All the love - all the power 💫 Thanks for this amazing breathing exercise.
Thankful for this. Days now has me feeling mentally stronger and more connected.

I have a question! Not sure if this is the best way to get answers but lets see. 

I cant keep up with thia rhythm of breathing. It feels stressing, I cant breath this fast even if I try. What does it mean? It is a sign of nervous system shutdown? Are my lungs bigger than most? Is my diaphram tight? Or is it normal?

Holding breath after exhaling is way difficult to me. Holding the recovery breath longer is way easier, I can keep it up for almost a minute  even after that exhale hold (I can keep it up app. 30 sec). You note that breathing earlier is ok - but is there anything possibly risky for extending that recovery breath hold? I dont feel its bad, I just wanna make sure.

If you see this and reply, awesome! Thank you for all you do, have been coming back to your videos for years and hopefully one day I will join one of your workshops ❤
replies: ["It's absolutely fine if you can't match his pace exactly, just get good quality deep breaths from the stomach and chest. Some people slow down the video", "There's nothing wrong with you, that's all perfectly normal. Those things take practice. Just don't worry about going the same speed as the video, focus on fully filling your lungs. And don't force the breath holds, just breathe when you need to. With time these will become much easier ❤", 'Thank you both for responding!!! I obeyed by own rhytm now, focusing on full breaths at a slower pace and got a much more out of the practise, the tingly feelings, relaxation and more clarity - and was able to hold my breath for 75 SECONDS after the exhale (compared to 30 sec!!) Soooo thank you thank you community, so glad I asked❤']

I am living more comfortably than 99% of all humans that have ever existed. comment: Put it on 1/2 speed it sounds like the hof is pinching a loaf

A technical question:
From what I can see, Wim Hof breathing is hyper-ventilation. This stimulates the sympathetic nervous system and boosts adrenaline production.
As I understand it, what's beneficial is that adrenalin will temporarily increase a lot - much more than in the case of chronic stress. And this big increase in adrenalin will enable the body to regulate it better and bring it down to a lower level than before.

Am I right?
What do you think of this method for people whose adrenal glands have already been exhausted by chronic stress?
replies: ["Boosting the sympathetic nervous system is right but not the increasing adrenaline as far as I know.\nAlso the breath holds boost the parasympathetic nervous system, so it's affecting both parts. That's my understanding of it anyway ❤"]

comment:
Hello everyone, I did the Wim Hof breathing method during the pandemic for anxiety and I felt great. I literally don't know why I stopped practicing, probably because the anxiety was reduced by about 80%
However, about a week ago I had a panic attack while driving and I thought I was going to pass out, everything came back again, the feeling of anxiety, irritability, I was helpless for a couple of days. But I remembered what helped me then, Wim Hof breathing of course! I felt better immediately and was back to normal after 2 days of practicing breathing. The anxiety went down by about 50% after just a week of breathing, but yesterday I had a mini panic attack while driving again despite doing the Wim Hof method in the morning. Of course, I am aware that I just need to face it and continue with the breathing exercises and everything will be fine, I am interested in your experiences, whether your body "resists" or deliberately sends panic attacks when you treat it with breathing.
Thanks everyone, take a deep breath and thanks to Wim Hof!
Lets gooooo!!!!

comment: How often do you do this a day? Just in the morning or whenever you are stressed?
replies:
["That's up to you ❤
I do it every morning, I know others who do it before bed, and all kinds of other uses ❤", 'Every day after exercise shower etc before breakfast ( very important as feel so sick if tried eating before 😂) before I up and at em into the world again', 'Once - it’s an evening routine after shower! Sometimes I do the regular cleaning evening shower and finishing with cold but nowadays (1 month in) I’m doing cold showers in the morning as well - just water, woooooow it is such an amazing practice to feel like a new  human, if you haven’t tried, I wholeheartedly recommend it\U0001fa75 I know you’re commenting about breathing, but I would encourage you to try the morning showers as well because they are an amazing addition to the breathing! And remember if you start, your mind will go against you and will discourage you but you have to “just do it” without much thinking! 

Tip 1: start with like 30 second warm shower, then go to the cold gradually or just finish your normal warm shower with a few seconds lukewarm if you feel not too motivated to go into fully cold.
Tip 2: feet and arms first, few seconds, I go from down up. Head last and only for 1-3 seconds, I don’t immerse my head unless I wash my hair, so it’s not every time, but I do put cold on my face each time.
Tip 3: focus on long calm breaths (and never do this Wim Hof breathing with the breath holds in the water, very important!)


PS: Wim has here many Q&A videos if you have questions about both - they help a lot!']

- 1 tablespoon ground cinnamon
-1 tablespoon grated fresh ginger

Over medium-low heat add water and turmeric, mix for about 6 to 10 minutes, until you get a thick paste. Adjust the thickness with more water or more turmeric.
Turn off the heat and add the rest of the ingredients and mix until well homogenized.
Let cool.
Bottle it in a glass container with a lid. Lasts 4-5 weeks in the fridge.


How to use:
1 teaspoon of the pasta with hot milk and sweeten with honey.

Do not use more than a teaspoon daily', '@@Rosales79Diegofantastic!!  Thank you for this ❤', 'Love hearing stories like this! Good for your son too!']

comment: I’ve developed this new style of breathing with Wim’s method. I call it’s “Jerm’s accordion breathing”. Sit Indian style. Then you empty your lungs and hunch your face over your shins bending at the abdomen. When you breathe in, you straighten your back upright with good shoulder posture “phooly” inhaling through both the nose and mouth. As you lean back you can feel the air start to fill your lungs and when your fully extended you should feel the upper cavity of your lungs full as well. When you bend back over you breathe out all the air and the actual movement helps push the air in and out. Kinda like an accordion lol. I’ve done this a few times now and the third round today had me shaking like I was on my 100th cup of coffee. All da ❤ and all da 💪

comment:
When my relationship ended, I felt like my world was crumbling around me. The pain was so intense that it was almost tangible, like a heavy weight pressing down on my chest. I didn't know how to cope, how to move forward, until I stumbled upon Wim Hof's breathing technique.

At first, I was skeptical. How could something as simple as breathing possibly help me through this agony? But I was desperate, willing to try anything to find relief from the relentless ache in my heart. So, with nothing to lose, I gave it a shot.

As I sat there, following Wim Hof's instructions, something incredible happened. With each deep breath, it was as if a wave of calm washed over me, soothing the turmoil within. For the first time since the breakup, I felt a sense of peace, however fleeting it may have been.

But I didn't stop there. I made a commitment to myself to practice this breathing technique every day, no matter how painful it felt at first. And slowly, but surely, I began to notice a shift. The pain didn't disappear overnight, but it became more manageable. I could breathe a little easier, think a little clearer.

What surprised me most, though, were the physical benefits. I had always heard about the mind-body connection, but I never truly understood it until now. With each inhale, I could feel tension melting away from my body, leaving me feeling lighter, more energized.

But perhaps the most profound change of all was the way it helped me reconnect with myself. In the midst of heartache, it's easy to lose sight of who you are—to become defined by your pain. But through this practice, I rediscovered my inner strength, my resilience.

Today, as I look back on that dark period of my life, I am filled with gratitude for the role that Wim Hof's breathing technique played in my healing journey. It wasn't a quick fix, nor was it a cure-all. But it was a tool—a lifeline—that helped me navigate the stormy seas of heartbreak and emerge stronger on the other side. And for that, I will be forever grateful.
Finally got the time to do this regularly again 😋

comment: Still love it
How could y’all survive a whole minute bruh i can’t breathe and im only like 15 sec
replies: ['Practice, you’re gonna get there soon! It’s because you have enough oxygen in your blood when deeply breathe before, so you can easily make 1, 2 or more minutes breath hold when you’ve practiced enough. But make sure you also breathe properly before holding breath. No shallow breaths but deep ones into the belly and lungs. Inhales and exhales are not supposed to be like, squeezing every single inch of your lungs, just go with guidance rhythm. Besides, the length of your breath hold doesn’t determine the quality of the exercise. It’s beneficial regardless of the length of the breath hold. Do what you’re feeling comfortable with, don’t push it as Wim says. There is also a beginner version of this video, so maybe go with that one first:)', 'It also depends on the activity you do before this exercise; I’d say the more I am relaxed, the longer I can hold my breath. 1:30 minute is no problem and I haven’t been doing this that long to be a pro (just about a few days, and a year ago for some days). Idk if you move during the exercise but that also take some oxygen (like I urgently needed to scratch my nose🤣). You should be completely relaxed.\n\nBut everyone is different, so find your own comfortable limit and slowly go with it every day you’ll see how it will go. I’ve heard people say some days are better than other when they can hold more, some not so much and that’s normal.']

comment: Is there any advice on how to manage a 1:30 minute breath hold?
replies:
["Just don't push it, breathe if you need to breathe. As you get better it'll come naturally ❤", 'Yeah, think about something else. Your cat, the Galapagos, anything else but breathing', 'thanks so much 
@@Sandalwoodrk', 'awesome, thank you 
@@Aksm91ManNavar', 'You don’t have to, just do what you’re comfortable with and keep practicing; you’ll be surprised how quickly you can get to that limit and further. Also, I suggest really relax your body, don’t be too active before (I do it before sleep so my body is slower, ready to sleep), also don’t move while exercising as it takes away some oxygen too (I needed to scratch my nose for example😂) 
Also the short length of the breath holds doesn’t mean the benefits are less of. It’s very beneficial to your body and mind no matter what is your current limit. Just keep going and getting back to it daily to build a new amazing habit.😊']

comment: Guys!!! This is crazy! I did cold shower today after doing the breathing exercises for a week once in a day. I thought 30 seconds will be good for a start but it was a good 2 minutes and I STOPPED FEELING ANY COLD AND ACTUALLY MY BODY ENJOYED THE COLD! I was so surprised that my body literally neutralized all the “ugly cold” I thought I will be feeling first thing in the shower (it was cold for maybe 10 first seconds and then my body just started to warm itself as the cold continued). As he said “don’t think, just go” so I did with the cold shower and I can imagine how people feel in the cold water when they go outside - their body enjoys it!!! I think I discovered something amazing that I never discovered before. I used to do hot->cold water in the morning some year ago but stopped and I didn’t do the breathing so I always felt like I need hot shower before cold because I HATED cold in the morning. I hated the discomfort of cold. But now?! Wow, I want to do this daily!!! It’s like a miracle how my body reacts now! Maybe I also changed something in my mind after I decided I’ll just GO into the shower without any warm/hot shower before. I love it!!!
replies: ["That's so great to hear, thank you for sharing here, your enthusiasm is contagious!", 'Well done', '@@BabyteethMore Your comment made me smile!🫶😁 I know the key is to be consistent… And also, I’ve heard sometimes motivation isn’t there for our goals in general which is normal, so the discipline (self persuasion to JUST DO) has to replace it in times like that. This time, I won’t excuse myself from doing these amazing habits because “I have no motivation” or “I don’t feel like to do it” - we don’t need it all the time as long as we decide to control what the mind will do and not that mind and comfort controls us💪']

comment: Thank you so much.
Utilidade pública

For others who also have been doing this everyday for years at this point - Has anyone changed up part of the video because you've found a different/better benefit? I find listening outside usually is most effective, sitting cross-legged. But sometimes, I hold my breath in round 2 from 13-25 (like we do for the 60/90 sec periods after each round), and then breath normally with the video for the last 5 until the hold. In the 3rd round, I hold it but for less. Maybe from15-23 breath count, and then I continue with Wim. For whatever reason, I find it helps me get to that place of nothingness that I search for when I meditate. 

I also am lucky enough to get a free gym membership because of child goes there for daycare, so I spend 25 a month to use a hydra bed at the gym that massages your back. My "ritual" is doing the 10 min Wim Hof video during my 10 minute massage bed session. It add's an extra element that helps the little muscles around the body really relax.

Anyone else have their own variations?
I always need to stretch like I just woke up after this. ☺️

7 increases confidence that we can achieve things which may be difficult
8 It brings on a calm that keeps away anxiety
9 A sense of gratitude that we can still be alive and breathing

Hello everybody !..! Hello Wim !..!
It's amazing how you feel when you do it for the first time. I had such strong tingling in my whole body and fingers of course during the first round, then during second and third bit less,... it was on FEB 2021. Fantastic feeling. I knew right away, that it was a gamechanger !..!
Later on, next days and sessions you feel it less and less, but it just the evidence that body gets use to hiperventilation as for anything else. It's just the first shock and natural high. BANGER !..!

Another thing - holding your breathe. First time it's difficult to keep it longer than a minute, but on and on - I reached 3 minutes easily... !..!
I checked the options with push-ups. 30 inhales and after last exhale - I held the breathe and did 30 push-ups with no breathing. It was easier than with breathing... Magic... !..!
I was doing it due to my absence of alcohol and other stuff, meditation (as such) was cool but too weak for me. That was THE ANSWER for the prayers from my body...

Now mind this!!!
I returned to the sessions NOW after 2 years break due to the other issues in my life and remembering exactly what I should expect - the same tingling, BUT during third round of inhale/exhale I felt such a strong tightness of my lower stomach, that I had not felt ever before ...  unbelivable ...

I've always had an open mind for these kind of simple but efficient methods. My father every sunday (he's 88 now) goes hot/cold/hot/cold showers, his godfather used to do it the same. He was around 93 when he died - no diseases at all. He had lived through two worldwars ... YEAH !..!

Period. 
Thanks Wim, you are THE MAN. I hope you still enjoy Poland and Śnieżka Mountain !..!

All the BEST to you Man !!!

replies: ['inhale with nose, exhale with mouth', 'Exhale through the mouth, inhale however it feels best for you (I personally inhale and exhale through my mouth while doing this exercise).', 'you could do whatever you’d like', 'I alternate, whatever feels best at the time.', '@@angie0876 People tend to overthink and overcomplicate this imho. I remember him once saying something like "get the air in anyway you like, you can get it in through the ass for all I care." 😂 On a serious note, other things are much more important, breathe in and out rhythmically and without a break, take really full breaths, don\'t do it superficially. You need to do diaphragm breathing while doing the exercise to really do it properly. Imagine you have two deflated balls in your body, one in the stomach and one in the chest. With each breath you inflate the ball in the stomach and then the ball in the lungs in one fluent motion. You might not do it correctly right away, but if you do a conscious effort and practice it, it becomes second nature. You will notice the breath hold become easier, you will also be able to hold the breath longer after a while.']

comment:
Testimonial. I never believed in health nuts that were super strict with their diet and took tons of vitamins and exercised themselves to exhaustion. I'm 24 now, and for the past year, I've felt like a 70 year old man. I was never more than 175 lbs as a 6'0 tall guy, but I never had energy. All I wanted to do was sleep and watch TV. I work in one of the physically easiest day trades there is, HVAC, and I was always tired whenever I was doing anything. I perpetually had low energy. 

I started taking multivitamins, magnesium threonate, mushroom complex capsules, and lions mane mushroom capsules, and started this breathing exercise for a round or two every day, and I feel like I was 10 again. I didn't change much else, and I feel better than any pharmaceutical drug I've ever taken trying to feel better. Strattera, bupropion, methylphenidate, dextroamphetamine... Nothing made me feel as good as this breathing exercise, and this stuff doesn't have any negative side effects. Maybe I'll take the health nuts a bit more seriously from now on...

comment: Here's my input! Have been doing this I think for half a year now? It really helps, is my TL;DR summary. . Helps what? Mind, mood, endurance and for me addresses my asthma. This and cold exposure has really helped me in many ways. I do notice some days my holding is lower, some days its a dream, but I haven't got a handle on everything else in my life. Its easy to impliment and I seldom forget a day. In jan 2022 I was riddled with panic attacks and thought I couldn't leave the house, now I am back to enjoying life and this was one of the things that helped me immensely. Now, I had read a lot of comments from people saying its a miracle cure from first time- well, not quite in my case, but you will see improvements pretty fast and sticking with it seems to be the thing that does the business. It is uncomfortable at start ngl.  I feel more like myself, more comfortable and have been able to move away from my vices (smoking, drinking, overeating, negative thinking and stress). Blessings to everyone and please do give this a go!

comment: What’s the best order for these 3 things? Can’t seem to find the right info that is actually the best way to do it. (Strength training gym, wimhof breathing, cold exposure)
replies:
['I like gym -> cold shower -> breathing', 'Best breathing, cold showe, exercise, hot shower', '@@ohbie yeah but that’s the thing. For cardio it’s perfect, but for strength training it’s terrible to do a cold shower after workout', '@@jankozamborsky5339 how much time between cold shower and gym? Because it gives you testosterone boost, but it makes your body too stiff to go directly to it', 'WHM: lowers heartrate + gives best result with a low heartrate during it
Cold shower: temporarily raises heartrate, then lowers it, also easier to stay at ease with a low starting heartrate
Sports: Raise heartrate.
You could try all sequences its partly personal but the one things thats objectively true for anyone is that the Wim Hof method is best done either first or at least after some break time after sports, that is, if you want the best result from the WHM. Safe bet probably is: WHM->cold shower-> sports because you have only enhancing effects for the next thing with that sequence and no downsides']

replies: ["Yes, breathe at your own slower pace that feels natural for the time being. Only start keeping up with the pace of the guidance when it feels relaxed. May take some time, took me 2 weeks when starting I think. \nTo the other part, this might sound easier than done, but fear and anxiety are just reactions to a thought, Don't have the thought and here is no fear. Focus on your heartbeat or meditate, anything that works for you to either not think at all or replace the thought with one thats not scary whould prevent the fear. If you find something that succeeds in this during the breathing a few or maybe even one time the fear may disappear completely because you know your body can handle the exercise and there is nothing to fear", '@@apocalypsed8 wow thank you for that amazing answer, that helps a lot!']

hello ! i wanted to start doing this since i have generalized anxiety and panic disorder, and im worried about how my body may feel, since every new symptoms cause me to basically panic, mostly about feeling dizzy and i have huge fear of fainting, anyone that has done this exercise could tell me about their experience and give me tips maybe ? thank you 🙏
replies: ['Try to do it slowly, if you feel uncomfortable just take a step back, but otherwise just try it and go till the end. Good Luck', 'I think it will help - because to get around your panic issues you need to get comfortable with the fact sensation can change in our body - and that isn’t always a threat . At the moment you are understandably running away from anything that resembles fear because of course panic attacks are deeply uncomfortable. But the fear of those feelings is feeding the fear. Try it starting with the beginner version and start reclaiming your body !❤', 'As someone diagnosed with GAD, I am comfortable saying the Wim Hof breathing method combined with cold showers (not at the same time of course) has been the most effective means of controlling, reducing and even eradicating my anxiety. I did find it a little stressful to try to "keep up" with the exact breaths and counts, so I breathed the best I could without pushing myself too hard in the first few days. Use this video as a guideline and not a strict template, it\'s okay. You can even play the video at 75% speed and take less deep breaths if that\'s what your body wants. The fact that you are here, and come back, is huge.', 'I have all the same problems, especially the fear of fainting from the dizziness. I have never had a problem with this, been doing for 3 years pretty much every day', 'I go into it thinking this is a recovery tool, it’s going to help you with all these symptoms']

Man! As a heavy smoker (trying to quit) I thought I coudn't pause for more than 20 secs and certainly not a minute, but I managed to do 50 secs. 2nd round, "hold for 1:30" I thought "sh**, no way", so I just closed my eyes and held it for as long as I could. Then I panicked and inhaled, looked at the time, there was just 4 secs left. Last round was easy and now I just feel euphoric! Thank you so much! Can't wait to try this tonight before sleep
replies:
['Well done!', 'Quit mentally first. Think about all the times u usually smoke and think about how youre not smoking these times and that it feels ok without smoking. 
Decide to quit mentally but dont set a certain timepoint or date for quitting. One morning you will feel today Im done and you will not smoke no more and be happy with it. 
Or set a date if that feels better? 
3-5 days of withdrawel is normal but do a clean cut and dont take other nicotine-products. Cause as long as taking nicotine theres a great possibility for going back to smoking. 
Sorry for just chanting out this but I have limited time so I cant make a dialouge, but I hope my words will help you ❤', '@@Joe-bj7nz I read the Allen Carr book on quitting and after that I tried and failed. But a month later tried again and I was free of nicotine for a month, easily. But then I took a trip with smokers who were out smoking every 15 mins and thought "what the hell, I know how easy this is, I can smoke with them these couple days". Nope. It definitely wasn't, two more years have passed smoking and I'm planning on reading the book again. And I thank you for your advice, will come in handy I'm sure', '​@@heirapparent4877 Yes I hear you. I have fallen back many times but now Im free since july -23 (from nicotine.. we got this very strong nicotine in pouches and as minced tobacco up here in Sweden that go under the upper lip.. called snuff.. or snus in native language). 
I started when I was eleven yo and also was a smoker many years.. think I quit smoking about 2013 cause of respitory problems.
They say quitting with snus is harder then quitting with smoking cause of the high level of nicotine.. but Im not sure.
I tried quitting both several times during about 30 years.. and also tried reducing the amount to about 2 cigarettes a day or 2-3 pouches of snus..even one a day. 
 And as long as I took ever so slightly amount of nicotine I would fall back hard and then it was years of not having a thought of quitting passing again. 
But I did a "hard stop" (no nicotine at all) once or twice and had the record of over a year. 
But this time I knew it was final and that I will never start again.. and I hardly ever think about nicotine.  Its just gone from my system and Im free.. cant even hardly remember how addicted I was to it.. used to wake up several times during the nights and take another snus sleeping with it. 

So thats what I mean with quitting mentally first.. just go over every scenario when the smokes feels best and make peace with those moments not smoking. Feeling good without it. And also think on how good it will feel hanging out with smokers and being a role model showing them not smoking and being social and have fun without it.. hanging out with them when theyre smoking without being tempted. You will just be free from it and have all your health becoming stronger. 

And this breathing excercise will help both quit smoking and give you a great mental health🎉 

And as a personal thought if you combine it with the cold exposure (as the other part of the wim hof metodh) u can start recovering most physical issues too. 
That book sounds good too! 

Best of luck to ya.. u will make it 🎉', "You're not a smoker trying to quit. You're not a smoker anymore. You need to change your mindset."]

I discovered Wim and his method via Vice documentary. Watched it for 40 minutes and went straight to the cold shower. For 5 minutes I was looking at the cold water and couldnt find the courage to get under it but when I did everything stopped. For 10 seconds I couldnt think of anything other than running away bcs it was freezing. Then I was like “wait a sec wheres all that noise my head, oh this isnt so bad.” I felt alive. After that whenever I got the chance I tried to teach my friends my family. Thank you Wim. I owe you my life. To meet you and go to the camp at Poland is my dream!

comment: A special thanks to @Yahkiawankened for this gem!! I panicked though during the 1st 30 and hold. Now I'm okay after focusing and listening to your voice allowing the natural guidance realm to take place. Hopefully I will now bring more peace and less to no anxiety with no meds!! 🕉🕉☮☮❣❣

I want to do this but I’m scared I will pass out, it feels very fast and hyperventilating- can someone educate me on how this works
replies:
['breathing very quick gets a lot of CO2 out of your body, very quickly. so the tingly feeling is because the blood vessels that supply your brain narrow as you’re overly oxygenated (this is a GOOD thing!). a tingly sensation is normal, and even if you pass out it’s okay, your body will take over when you pass out and you’ll wake up soon after. just don’t do all 3 rounds, maybe start with 1, and go from there!', 'Lie down and relax, build up to deeper breathing over time', "You don't have to be scared of passing out if you:
1) Do the breathing at your own pace that is comfortable for you, until you feel comfortable at wims pace. Can take a few weeks
2) Stop for the moment if you feel anything uncomfortable, you will never have to pass out if you listen to your body's signals
This is in the end, a relaxation exercise, doing anything forced or that does not feel well is counterproductive to what it should achieve, also during the breathing fully relaxed all muscles and dont breathe too forcefully, it will make for an overall nicer experience", 'He has a beginner breathing video that I started out with']

comment: Writing this during a breath hold. Takes my mind off the hold!!! The world is strange, life is beautiful. Embrace it! Accept the totality of it. Time to breathe.
replies: ['Life is not beautiful and no sane person could ever come out with such a preposterous statement. Right now while you are holding your breath there are people dying in agony, others crying out in misery and grief and heartache. Others still are homeless, starving, freezing or going through unimaginable torture. In your backyard there are earthworms being torn apart by ants and in the Serengeti there are gazelle being brought down by lions. Life, as Buddha and others pointed out, is suffering. Yes, holding your breath stills the mind and gives a nice peaceful feeling, but do not make the mistake of conflating that with a silly hippy notion of life being beautiful. It has beauty _in_ _it_ but as a phenomenon in itself, it could not be more ugly.', "Awesome . . .Beautiful, positive, accepting thoughts. This is what it takes to find a little sanity, calm, transcendence and even peace during this weird period. It will pass too into a better or more difficult time. We'll see but in the meantime as saint Seraphim of Serov said . . . 'Find peace and thousands around you will find their salvation'. Save yourself, find healing and peace for yourself then you can give and help others. This is the golden order. I'm not saying you can not also give out of your pain. Also I'm not saying to not help or acknowledge pain, misery, terrible & horrific events happening in other parts of the world and I understood your acknowledgement of them in the word 'weird'.", "And yet life is beautiful. If you cannot see it, keep doing the breathing, and try to stop all that thinking you're doing", "@@jackfiddleton Repeating the same thing I have just shown to be untrue doesn't magically make it any less false. Also, while on the surface level your comment is meant to be 'friendly advice', in reality it is ironically condescending, disgustingly flippant, laughably hypocritical and just plain dumb. I've been doing breathwork longer than Wim Hof has been alive and am well aware how pleasant it can feel. That is all it is though. Do not arrogantly and ignorantly fool yourself into believing there is anything mystical about it. In no way does limiting the brain's oxygen supply change the reality of a terribly cruel world. In essence, your 'advice' is nothing more than an appeal to selfishness, i.e. so long as *I* feel okay then 'life is beautiful'. Reality doesn't work that way and I would advise you to cut back on all that breathing you're doing and to start thinking instead.", "@@iankogneeto4882 Life can be both beautiful and suffering at the same time, and that's precisely what Wim Hof teaches. I suspect you're upset for a different reason. Maybe you've been left alone too long. Either way, next time you're doing the breathing, stop thinking so much. You're no good at it."]

comment: Anyone today

LONG COMMENT ⚠️ 
 ❤️ 2 months ago I quit niquitine after nearly 20 years of smoking although the last 2 years I have been vaping not smoking tobacco but same in the sense ive been poisoning myself for a long time. Then 1 month ago I was in bed about to fall  asleep and I felt like something was stuck in my throat so I got up coughed drank water and basically had a full blown panic/anxiety attack and convinced myself something was wrong with me to the point i thought about hospital my amazing partner comforted me and held me til it passed and i got over myself. Then 2 weeks ago while eating dinner I choked on a crispy chip and felt like it was stuck in my throat the feeling of dread and panic set in again like the first time but now kind of justified i forced myself to cough I also beat my chest hard a few times I was stood up coughing while bent down with my head by my knees. I coughed and panicked to the point I was physically sick and didn't go back to finnish my dinner then next day all I ate was half a tin of soup and the day after that I barely ate again through fear. And ever since the second episode almost on a Dailey basis I have been having the worst waves of anxiety I've ever had in my life im still probably not eating as much as i should. Sometimes its simply because I still feel something like a slight pressure in my chest or a burp stuck in my throat on occasion (probs something to do with no longer smoking) but kind of feels like the first episode and its most days so it's been freaking me out causing heart palpitations at times and making me feel very uneasy. And sometimes I feel it comes on for no reason iv been to the doctors since to have blood tests done all was well and I'm waiting on an ecg. I've done this video for 10 days in a row now and I can do all the breath holds and follow the video there's been maybe 2 days where I've had to breathe a few seconds early on the last hold and some days i can pause to hold a few seconds longer. I feel its definitely helping me manage my anxiety and at the same time it gives me confidence in my body because if there was something wrong with me like my heart lungs or throat I wouldn't be able to do the whole video the way I am. I don't usually share this deeply but wanted to say how this video Is now my favourite part of my day it leaves me feeling strong and calm I'm thinking once iv done a month of doing it every day I'm going to try cold showers aswell. sometimes your head can make you physically feel if you give credit to negative thoughts and its confusing for me sometimes but wim hof is helping me in ways I didn't think possible thankyou for reading if you got this far all the peace and all the love  to you all ❤️

comment: "Anyone today  ''✋you are amazing I'm proud of ya

I am using this (as *one* of the tools) to successfully manage and first aid my PoTS (postural tachycardia orthostatic syndrome - i.e. my body doesn't pump enough oxygenated blood to my brain) symptoms. This has been life changing because I was using full wheel pose, but I also have EDS (Ehlers Danlos syndrome - i.e. hypermobility) and super stretchy poses like that are not good long term for me, especially since I was doing like 5 a day. Thank you so much for this technique. <3
replies: ['What else do you find helpful?', "I'm pretty sure I have hypermobile eds. What are your pots symptoms? Just so you know eds can cause slipping rib syndrome so if you ever feel your rib cartilage break or ribs start hurting clicking popping or moving look into SRS."]

comment:
Im 23 im asthmatic so i have a lot of difficulty breathing when doing sport.
I discovered wim hof with the book breath by james nestor really interesting btw...
I have now been doing wim hof for a round six month and holy shit that helps a lot!!!
I can go to wrestling and sumo practrice without thinking , i might have a asthma attack.
The breathing really helped to learn that it's something i can controll, and the day i don't do it , i feel it when i do any kind of cardio.
To any asthamatic people that are thinking well this really work ? yes it does 
Also breathing by the noose helped me a lot with asthma. The breathing didn't cure my asthma but it helps so much!
To anyone that is reading have a wonderfull day and a good breathing session !
Thank you so much Wim Hof you are a real life saver 😁
Shared this link to my friend, hoping this will help to cure her heart problem/hepatitis 🙏🏼🙏🏼

comment: Be aware that this method cause tinnitus and other ear symptoms in some people, that can turn your life upside down. Its a direct link to the breath holding. It probably happens to relatively few, but you dont know if its you. Believe me, you dont want this. Youre warned.
replies: ['Only the mouth breathing technique can cause tinnitus -- the nose method is perfectly safe.', '@@nicedream92 i was breathing with the nose, and did not push to the head, still got it as a direct consequence of the breathing. Dont do this breathing! The fact that Wim & his team dont take it seriously is even one more reason to stay away from this method. This madness has to stop before even more people get hurt, holding your breath isnt a natural thing humans should do every day.', '@@schmeltisdid you get the tinnitus from the 15 secs recovery? Because i’m thinking of cutting this down.', '@@GSaiff i got it from the breath holding going into the recovery breath, but i didnt push. Ive read many getting it even though cutting the recovery. Just stop it!! There are thousands of people struggling with this and the Hofers only care about money; promoting mental health and teaching a method that causes tinnitus, which can make people suicidal, oh the irony. How they can do this with their family story is beyond my understanding.', "@@schmeltis It's hard to take your comments seriously when 99.9% of the comments are positive. the thing is that with any 'solution' and in any realm imaginable there will always be people that the solution either won't help or will make their problems worse. this applies to ANYTHING. thing is, just because some people are allergic to certain pills it doesn't mean it won't help the vast majority. such is the case with this. the only difference is that you can't evaluate beforehand whether you are 'allergic' to it or not, otherwise it's the same as with anything. a risk exists but it's very small, yet the benefits can be enormous. I agree that this should be mentioned clearly so that people can make their choice - but most would do it anyway."]

comment: Wim Hof is the Greatest!!

Forced hyperventilation can have several negative effects, including:

Heart problems: Excessive breathing can affect the functioning of the heart.
Lung problems: Hyperventilation can affect the functioning of the lungs.
Nervous system problems: Hyperventilation can cause nervous system problems.
Drug reactions and poisonings: Certain drugs and toxic substances can cause hyperventilation.
Infections: Certain infections can cause hyperventilation.
Pregnancy: Hyperventilation can be more common during pregnancy.
Liver diseases: Certain liver diseases can cause hyperventilation.
Loss of consciousness: Severe hyperventilation can cause loss of consciousness.
Brain death: Severe hyperventilation can cause brain death.
Dizziness: Hyperventilation can cause dizziness.
Tingling in the fingers: Hyperventilation can cause tingling in the fingers.
Narrowing of the blood vessels supplying the brain: Hyperventilation can reduce the CO2 level in the blood, which can narrow the blood vessels supplying the brain.
Therefore, it is very important to only perform forced hyperventilation under proper supervision and in a safe environment.

comment: Here again
GRATITUDE.

I am a recovered fentanyl and benzo addict of two years that has been on a journey of self discovery and healing.
I discovered Wim last month. Although I’ve experimented with cold showers and meditation in the past Wim’s videos have motivated me to be more consistent. 

After high school I was headed to college in Boston to study Neuroscience on a scholarship, but fell victim to drugs after being abused by a family member who was jealous of my achievements. When I got clean two years ago even though I wanted to go back to school I felt incompetent because of all the damage done to not only my brain, but my soul. 

Well, I’ve been following Wim’s techniques for about a month now. Daily cold showers, and breathing… I can’t begin to explain the liberation I’ve felt. Tears of happiness flow from my eyes as I write this — I just enrolled in college yesterday, and I WILL be getting that neuroscience degree I’ve always dreamed of since I was a young girl.

These methods have relit the fire in my soul. I feel at peace, and powerful at the same time.

You’ve changed my life, Wim. Thank you.

And to everyone else : YOU CAN ACHIEVE ANYTHING YOUR HEART DESIRES!!! I believe in you. 

Love you all!!!

comment:
Started this video with 74,362,968 views and by the time I emerged from this transformative journey, the count was at 74,363,489. That's over 500 kindred spirits from around the globe taking the plunge with me in that exact moment. 🌍✨

There’s something incredibly powerful in knowing that this video isn’t just a series of views—it’s a living, breathing movement of people expanding their limits, one breath at a time. Each view is a new believer, each minute another brave soul joining this life-changing voyage.

Give it a try: Note down the view count before and after your practice – it's a beautiful reminder that we're all part of this vast Wim Hof community, growing stronger together. 🌐❄🔥

How many were with you during your session? Drop a comment below and let's celebrate this amazing journey as a collective!
replies: ['126 people with me doing this', '513 people doing this with me. 🌎💙✨']

comment: Do you exhale through the mouth?

comment: I had a bad neck injury 5 yrs ago, which has strained all the muscles in my throat, causing me to have a voice problems when speaking. I went silent and in pain for years. Im also a singer so I had to stop expressing myself. Though it has been a long and extremely humbling journey, I find myself coming back to the wim hof method and it brings me to tears how well it works. The breathing almost activates my deeper strained muscles and relaxes them. I’m on top of my breath and my life, which in turn has given me the strength to recover. The breathing has also helped my singing and I’m beginning to write and record songs again like I used to before my injury. There is hope for everyone. Much love to you all.
replies: ['happy to hear that, Good luck with everything', 'Gloria Cote here, yes this breathing is miraculous in every way.  You are recovering 🙏', 'There is indeed hope for us all xx much love to you on your journey']

comment: Gratitude.

I’m wondering if I accidentally did some minor brain damage to myself. I’ve been doing Wim Hof for over a month now. I’ve gotten good at ignoring the urge to breath. Curious, I tried to push myself during a breath hold, and go for over two minutes. I could feel a sort of euphoria come over me, so during the next breath hold, I tried to go even longer.

I got this feeling of being submerged. I had gone for two and a half minutes. Realizing this, I let go. My ears were ringing. The back left part of my head, right next to my spine, had this weird sensation. I was quite panicked. 

Did I do some weird brain damage to myself? Did I shave off an IQ point or two? Have I forgotten a precious memory that I now don’t know I even had?
replies: ['Im no expert, but I think from what you write, Its your thinking brain wanting to be in «control» and want to make sense of everything and try to «protect» you.', 'honestly man , i think you might have cause some problems , better safe then sorry get it checked out as soon as possible', 'No you didnt lose any memories or iq lol. The wim hof method to some can give you tinnitus which is your ears ringing. It is still safe to practice the breath holds', 'You said you were ignoring the urge to breathe, which is probably the cause of the issues. You should be able to do the breathe hold without feeling the urge to breathe', 'You’re fine']

replies: ['Anxiety comes from negative belief systems and possible trauma. Do two rounds of wim? Try ice baths, up your magnesium and tell yourself how awesome you are ALL DAY until you believe it! ❤', "\u200b@thecrystalgecko thx for the reply. Sorry but anxiety doesn't only come from negatieve belief or trauma. If it was only that 'simple'.", "The effect of the exercise rises and falls with how you do it. If you dont let your mind wander, so meditate or focus on heartbeat during and fully relaxed your muscles, especially between the shoulders and around the heart area the effect will skyrocket. But sometimes we are too stressed and our hearrtrate is so elevated that it can be harder to control, I would recommend to not follow Wim's breathing speed in that case but breathe slower at a comfortable tempo for you, this will usually prevent raising your anxiety. Alternatively, if you have to come from a very stressed state adding rounds to the 3 can also really help, because for instance you can be as relaxed after 3 rounds as you normally already are after 1 or even before starting, but adding 2 extra rounds can in those days still get you to the desired state you normally get after 3 (sorry for rambling)"]

replies: ['It’s meant to get you closer to your body by focusing on the most basic and crucial need that we have', 'It also has been shown in a scientific experiment by like Duke or MIT or something, to hyper-oxygenate the blood leading to a quicker immune response. Wim Hof was actually apart of the experiment. You can look it up. Pretty cool stuff. The trick is to relax the body so that your veins relax and allow more blood to flow in quicker succession. A lot of negative attention is given to the hyper-oxygenation as being bad because usually, when we hyper-ventilate we are in a stress filled response which tightens our veins and when this happens with hyper-oxygenated blood it can lead to things like strokes and aneurisms. But, by relaxing the body we are negating these rare occurrences. Don’t take my word for it though. All the info is available online from reputable sources. Good luck.', 'His book explains it in scientific detail']

comment: Thank you Wim 🙏 Wish you a beautiful day and magnificent week ahead ✌️
Day 30 🎉❤

An amazing man. Scientists and doctors and philosophers should all collectively resign their jobs and study Wim Hof fulltime. They might actually make some progress in their fields...the type that benefits humanity instead of a few undesirables. 

Here is my challenge to myself. I am 57 and i have nothing and everything. As a child i suffered extreme sexual and mental abuse and have never had the courage to acknowledge it let alone resolve it. 

I tried suicide a few times and failed with great flair even when i drove my car at 90 mph into the central reservation of a motorway, rolling three times before ascending a grass embankment finalling landing on the car roof. I walked away, literally, with cuts and fractured ribs and returned to my work the following day. NB: I waited until 2am for the motorway to be clear of other cars. 

Since then, crippled with self disgust, crushing anxiety, i have worked and worked and married three times over. I self medicated with obssessions and anything else that would divert my attention. 

I worked bullshit jobs that make other people richer and that barely serviced my accumulating debts and obsessions. 

And then at 50 i found myself struggling to find regular work despite recommendations and referrals from many ex bosses and colleagues. 

So here i am at 57. I live in a room in my sisters house. I have no job, no possessions left to sell. I am diagnosed with three so called 'disorders' and taking prescribed stimulants and anti depressants which do not work but are incredibly difficult to kick because the withdrawal effects are severe. 

I was once an incredibly strong boy. Mentally able to bury the damage of the sexual abuse and physically very fit   thanks to the allconsuming sport of competitive swimming. I swam 15km per day 6 days a week and held records at county level. I trained harder than anyone else and despite incessant bullying (i was skinny and due to my metabolism unable to gain muscle bulk) i never stopped and i beat the bullies in the pool. 

But at 15 i stopped and the nasties from my past finally found a crack in my armour. And the depression, the mood dysregulation began. 

So now here is my challenge to myself. I am doing this for my twins who i love more than anything so that i can provide them with proof that we are all capable of achieving what others might claim to be impossible. 

One year from now i will no longer struggle to get out of my bed, no longer burn myself, no longer want to die, no longer need to live with family, no longer be addicted to pharmaceuticals. And more important than anything, i will be actively contributing to the good of humanity, making an intrinsic, positive, contribution. I have no idea how to do this but i will find the strength i had when i was a boy and i will achieve it one way or another. 

Thanks Wim Hof for the inspiration.
replies: ['This hit home thank you for sharing. Breathe and go into the cold everyday. The pain from your past are only old subconscious beliefs. Your subconscious beliefs can be rewritten ❤ look into dr joe dispenza or Abraham hicks. Both have different ways of changing our old thought patterns. I was lost once too and I have found my way out of the hole..I hope this helps and keep it up! You can be anyone you want to be- the tools to doing so are right here in YouTube ❤❤ Much love to you and your twins', 'Good Luck man, I hope everything will work out for you and your family', 'Continue every day with the breathing, go back to some form of physical exercise ( swimming?) if possible. All the best.', "@@mlk1965 thanks for the positive words and yes I'm making sure I walk for at least 2 hours daily and not strolling either! Take care.", '@@samimrad7710 thanks for the good wishes. Much appreciated and I wish you and your family well too.']

comment: Reading all these comments brings me to tears. Thank you all for sharing. I have suffered from debilitating anxiety day in and day out with daily headaches, depression and severe panic attacks for the last 2 years. It was affecting all aspects of my life. No one seemed to be able to help me. I no longer was able to find joy in the things I used to love. This has brought me so much hope and got me on my way to healing. This breathwork+cold exposure is POWER! Paired with homepathics, meditation/prayer, and exercise. I've been practicing for 7 months and I vow to never stop! Thank you Wim and all of you. It is comforting to know I am not alone on this journey. I didn't know how far I'd fallen from myself until now, I can look back and not even recognize the woman I'd become. It is still a work in progress, but I am finally feeling joy again. Here is to happiness and health, love you all! ❤

I'm 18 and in the darkest place I have ever been, a darkness that I didn't think was possible before, but is very common in basically all of my family. Before my nervous breakdown, I was very academic, I worked out a lot, I was very disciplined and was trying to develop my skills and educate myself. Then this hit and I believe I now know what suffering feels like. This has been a very humbling experience and one of great teaching, teaching me to be more compassionate towards others, because you truly never know what they're going through. Establishing a solid morning routine of movement, Wim Hof breathing and a walk acts as a glue holding my life together. Every day is difficult, but reading everyone else's experiences gives me hope that such suffering is not forever and happiness is possible again. Thank you Wim and thank you to everyone in the comments, what a community. Anyone reading this, I'm wishing you the best ❤

comment: As with anyone who does well and has something useful to say, all the keyboard critics are coming out of the woldwork sayijg how dangerous this method. It isnt. Just listen to your body,  follow wims guides, and your quality of life will skyrocket. ❤️

9 months ago I left a comment/update on here and I think it’s time for another one because what I have learned now may help others 

So now what I have discovered was my mindset or awareness of self was wrong going into this. I would come into this thinking by doing this would fix all my anxiety and be able to attack life and be a super human, but that is not the case. Yes I still use this and before when I was doing it it allowed me to get grounded and calm my mind for the time , but the main thing I had to do first was to radically accept my own reality and love all of it for what it was knowing that this life is mine to live and my past or my circumstances right now are just things I can learn from. So before when I wouldn’t accept my past I would do this and I would be upset later on why my meditation practice wasn’t fixing me. The answer was there was nothing to fix so I was fighting my own reality. So for people who are feeling like they are stuck (and I’m no expert but this helped me start my true healing) try to learn self acceptance and the big thing is once you do accept yourself know that the feelings and the problems will still be there but your mindset towards them can shift and then you can start to grow and forgive yourself older self for not knowing any better at the time. 
Now I use this exercise as a tool to help me ground myself and I see it as a privilege not a must have to. All these tools like meditation exercise nutrition therapy all this are not things that will “fix” you but rather tools to help you clear the mind to see your reality. I felt proud of myself and my body, for not only taking this step, but for getting me through this meditation.
I realised how blessed I am, and you are, just to be able to hold my breath for over a minute.

I feel endless amounts of gratitude for what my body does for me, and it hurts me to know how hard we are on ourselves and our bodies.
We don’t always focus and recognise the little things our bodies do for us daily. Even if that’s just waking us up in the morning!

Thank you Wim ❤

If you incorporate Wim's 'cold water therapy' along with the breath work, it works wonders for physical and mental health. I've been doing both since March this year, and have been able to taper down my meds. I'm now down to 12.5mg Pregabalin (prescribed for anxiety) and 4.5mg Mirtaz (prescribed for depression/anxiety) However, I must stress that I have done this VERY gradually, doing a 10% reduction every two months. I've been on these horrible drugs for most of my adult life, and came to the conclusion that after long term use, they've done me more harm than good. Big Pharma must be ecstatic that there are so many souls on these drugs. I also eat healthily (most of the time 😊) and have never felt better! Thank you soo much Wim Hof!
replies: ['❤❤❤', 'Wise to scale back gradually! All the best', 'Thoughts create emotions. Emotions can be changed by changing thoughts. Awareness of thoughts is required to change a thought. Set a random timer thru-out the day, maybe a dozen times. When the timer \'dings\' make a mental note of the actual time and ask yourself "What was I thinking?" Jot it down.  If the thought was beneficial, great, if not, say to yourself , "I don\'t need to think that". Continue to do this simple exercise until you can do so without the aid of a timer. If you\'re thinking worthwhile thoughts, or not, you can tell by your emotion Pay attention to how you feel.  (...and do your breathing routine).  🙂']

I struggle from major panick disorder,  anxiety and agoraphobia. I was curious about this so I've just tried it once so far,  it actually made me feel panicky through the entire session other than during the breath hold,  fight through it and the breath hold is relaxing as you're able to focus on your heartbeat and the tingly fingers and arms. I was on clonzepam twice a day for about a year, it and this past year have been the worst two years of my life (benzo withdraw) but I'm of all the medicine just trying to find my old self again. I'm going to judo trying this and try to understand how I'm feeling during so. Either way great vid! Glad it's helping some people.
replies: ['Best to try to fully relax during the exercise, dont let your mind wander, meditate or focus on heartbeat as you mention and fully relax all muscles, especially between the shoulders and in/around the heart. But still, when just starting may be better to do the 30 breaths on your own tempo because it might be difficult to keep up and feel forced. Took me also some time before I started following the guided speed of breathing. Good luck', "I've suffered from anxiety/depression for most of my adult life, and taken 'medication' for it. I started Wim Hof method (breathing and cold water therapy) in April this year and I truly believe that this is helping me come off these awful drugs. I'm doing my own (very slow) reduction/decrease of the meds, using a syringe to help me with the dilutions. In doing the dilutions, I can very slowly decrease the amount I'm taking each night. Currently down to 4.5mg of Mirt and 12.5 of Lyrica. Aim to be totally free by the end of the year. Stick with it and be consistent; it's life changing!", 'Try the beginners version if it’s to stressful for you', "Good advice to do the slower version.  Don't give up 🙏♥️🙏", 'Well because during the rapid breathing you will activate your Sympathetic Nervous System so you will be more anxious. Just battle through it. Then on the breath hold you activate your Parasympathetic System so you feel more calmer']

You can know how anxiety works, challenge your thoughts, be optimistic, etc.. but if your not working on also changing how your body physically handles stress, anxiety, negative emotions, etc.. as well then the anxiety will still linger because you have your mind balanced but not your body so it's important to make sure you do things like breathwork, meditation, exercise, etc.. to make sure your mind and body are connected
Pro Tip: This is great before a workout, especially in the morning. I'm able to run much longer after doing this.

replies:
['The point of this exercise is to connect more deeply with your body by focusing on the breaths you take. Good Luck', '@@samimrad7710 You can connect with your body by doing slower breathing too.

Long breath in, hold and an even longer breath out. Like the 4.7.8. technique I read bout recently. This activates the parasympathetic system and relaxes you and is good for anxiety and depression. Any therapeutic intervention I have ever had in the past 10 years promotes slow deep breathing...

...this type of breathing makes you hyperventilate and heightens anxiety and stress but each to their own...

The tingling or burning you feel in your arms is because of hyperventilating.', '​@@sarahlee9380watch "what I've learned"', 'it’s not unhealthy but yes, what many don’t know is that by hyperventilating we actually increase the carbon dioxide level In our blood. comment:
[Day 1 of NoFap]
Day 2 of NoFap, second time trying after breaking a 700 day streak
Day 3 of NoFap, going strong.
Day 4 of NoFap, hardly any urges so its really easy at this point of my journey. I think it'll get more difficult as my life gets more difficult (currently on holiday so minimal stress).
Day 5 of NoFap, went to a temple yesterday though I'm not religious or anything. Urges haven't really been effecting me. Socialising and excercise has been helpful. I am getting better at skateboarding, but it really hard.
Day 6 of NoFap, getting some urges, but still going strong. This little journal that I have going is helping a little, its better than the videos I used to make.
Day 7 of NoFap, did a workout last night and went skateboarding. First workout in a long time. This NoFap streak doesn't really feel like the other ones. Neither the urges of the benefits are really evident, so it feels a little easier. I do want to socialise more though, I hangout with friends every few days, but I think I have to make some new friends.
Day 7 of NoFap, I'm feeling a lot better than I did before I started this streak. At my MMA gym I've begun socialising a bit more, I've some progress to specific skill I'm working on and I have also just felt better in general. I don't know who will ever read this or why, but I've learnt a really useful idea recently which is to not follow on the foot steps of great people or people who you admire, but rather to seek what they sought. So, if we are to do this with some people who we look up to and individuals that do NoFap. Don't just blindly do NoFap because they did it, but realise that the true reason and the thing that they are doing NoFap is to have inner-peace and become better, kinder individuals. Remember you have no enemies.
Day 8 of NoFap, not much to say its just my 8th day.
Day 9 of NoFap, figures out I passed my semester in university after having initially failed a critical subject. I'm going to start private tutoring now (self-run) so hopefully that turns out well. I have to spend more time with my family tho.
Day 10 of NoFap, going well.
Day 11 of NoFap, some urges here and there, but overall pretty good. I woke up the earliest I have (without an alarm) in a while which was around 9:30pm. I finding that doing physical excercise such as bjj helps me sleep better at night. My phone and a laptop is an addiction at night though. Overall my life is improving, but I need to make some money, because I'm currently not working and am just spending. Which means that in a while the little money that I have in my savings will deminish.
Day 12 of NoFap, the reason is really hard to describe, but I've been waking up a lot earlier since starting my NoFap streak and have been sleeping earlier too. As in I wen't from waking up at 12:30pm to waking up at 10:45am, then 9:45am and today 8:45am. This is all without an alarm. Obviously with an alarm I can wake up whenever I wish, however, this was really surpising. I have a lot more time in my day now.
Day 13 of NoFap, did a BJJ and MMA class in the afternoon and in the morning I did a driving lesson which I did terrible in and couldn't really park properly and had a few other problems. Trying to start a tutoring business so I'm researching that. I socialised with some people at my mma gym which was nice. I've also made plans to hangout with two of my friends on Sunday. NoFap isn't really too difficult as of now. I'm trying to make each day count, rather than focussing on the streak. I moved my phone, laptop and iPad out of my bedroom so hopefully that makes me stop associated my bedroom or more specifically my bed with porn and masturbation. Other than that nothing too special about today.
[Day 14 of NoFap - no journal]
Day 15 of NoFap, I don't really care about my streak anymore. Had a wet dream which is kinda weird to talk about, but it is what it is. I'm starting to identify some deeper issues I have for the first time and I believe that they may be the cause of me watching pornography.
Day 16 of NoFap, no longer feeling like doing this commenting thing. still doing nofap, but this is kinda a waste of my time. i'll update if i relapse.
[Update 13/9/23] - still going strong not that anyone cares. I have a job now which is great and it means I can start investing some of my income. I also started working out somewhat consisently and just being healthier in general. I took a cold shower today or at least for part of the shower length. I've also being practicing yoga. Btw i have my licence now so I can drive anywhere I need to.
Does anyone else also feel vibration like tingles going through their body? Anyone know what that is?
replies: ['Yes i feel it too sometimes, it’s you connecting with your body and truly feeling what it’s like for the blood to go all over the place. Good Luck', '@@samimrad7710 ahhh alright thanks']

comment: My favorite Wim Hof quote, "Let the body do what the body do"
Thanks!

I have been practising the Mindfulness of Breathing technique https://www.youtube.com/post/UgkxIIDVgnLN8pF_fPOyoZ1nTjbLvvZcib6r as taught in this CD for about 2 years having read about it in Paramananda's  Change Your Mind  book and taken a real liking to it. However at times I struggle to remain focused on the breathing and thought that at such times this guided version might suit me. So after two years I finally decided to buy it! The first 7'24  of Track 1 of the CD is a body relaxtion which I do not use: I don't like body relaxation techniques and I find 27' just a little too long for meditation. The remaining 20' of gentle, guided meditation helps me tremendously to relax and stay focused. I find him's voice very soothing and whilst he is present to guide you through the 4 stages of the meditation, his presence is not intrusive or distracting. For the past two years I have tried to follow this technique as best I can with gentle meditation music despite music not being recommended. Having used this CD a couple of times I think I will try from now on to adopt a new routine of no music and just this CD as I find it so helpful. I realise now that the music really is distracting and I have enjoyed listening to the ambient sounds around me which I am normally unaware of. I can not comment on the other 2 tracks of Metta or Walking Meditation as I bought the CD solely to help me with the Mindfulness of Breathing and it does just that - very effectively. In my opinion this CD is money very well spent as it will guide you through a thoroughly useful and beneficial meditation technique and I don't think you can put a price on that.

comment:
This video cures hiccups 100%

Hiccups are caused by low blood pH. When you don't breathe often enough, carbon dioxide builds up in your blood and reacts with water to form carbonic acid, lowering your blood pH. By expelling the carbon dioxide,  you increase the pH of your blood and the hiccups go away. I've used this video to cure hiccups multiple times, not just for me, but also for friends and it's worked every time.
All the love...all the power 💐❤
I fkn love you sir Wim Hof ❤❤❤

comment:
I am fairly new to the Wim Hof Method. How many time per day should I do this breathing technique? I find it very helpful. I have been struggling with insomnia, anxiety, panic attacks, and depression for a few weeks now. Never had a problem with depression or panic attacks before April 2023. Cold showers have gotten me through some very tough times and I feel like I'm on the tail end of this terrible time in my life.

Today is day 46 of at least 2 cold showers per day. Started with 2 minutes and now I do 5 minutes consistently. Just to see how far I could go, I did 15 minutes yesterday.

comment: idk why but i cant hold the breath
replies: ["Don't worry man. It's about not being stressed. If you need to breathe, breathe. But in the first 30 breaths, make sure to keep them powerful and full. You are expelling the excess carbon dioxide from your body so you can hold your breath without worrying about the pain of carbon dioxide buildup. After that, just trust that your body will not be harmed and let go. Feel the things happening in your body as you hold your breath. The way blood flow is directed away from the extremities to conserve oxygen, how your heart begins to slow down, the way your fingers and toes feel after the blood has left them. It feels good."]

comment: Can this help before running?
replies: ["It depends. Maybe not directly before, but it will definitely build up carbon dioxide tolerance if you progressively overload the time you hold your breath. Carbon dioxide tolerance helps you run long distances without needing to breathe as much, and it increases the acidity of your blood which causes more oxygen to be used. So if you run long distance, that's a big plus."]

Edit2: I've been doing daily this for a while, and I notice sometimes after the breathing exercise I hear a tinnitus sound. It has always gone away, but I've seen posts on reddit from people claiming to have developed constant tinnitus from this breathing exercise. Since I need my ears and can't risk it, I have to stop doing the exercise at all. I haven't been properly trained in how to do this and I don't know the science behind tinnitus and the breathing exercise, and as long as both of those things are the case I cannot risk doing the exercise.

I finally got around to starting this. I surprised myself by going 1.5min on empty lungs. If I can find this comment after a month of doing this exercise each morning, I'll update with results. Also, in case you aren't aware, the left arrow key brings the video back 5 seconds making it easy to measure how much extra time you give your breath hold.

Edit: I've been doing this for a month now. The main things I notice are that I can hold my breath on empty lungs for at most about 1min50sec, instead of the 1min30sec limit I had before I started this. I also notice it's a bit easier to breathe through my nose when going to sleep (nasal breathing is good for you, and mouth breathing is bad). I will continue to do it and if in the months ahead I notice any differences I'll edit this comment.

Round 1: Breathe 30 times, no pause between the breaths then, on the last breath, breathe fully in, exhale and wait 1 minute without breathing. As 1 minute passes, inhale fully, hold for 15 seconds and let go, proceed to round 2.
Round 2 and 3: Same as round 1, except the waiting time is 1 minute and a half.

replies: ["Your lungs still have air in them even when you exhale, unless something happens like a lung collapse. Sort of like if you fill a tub  with gallons water, scoop out a quart and then dump in a fresh new quart - there's still lots of the old water there, mixing in with the new water. James Nester's book Breath is a great way to learn more about how a lot of this stuff works, like why you're actually building up more CO2 during this and why that's a good thing. (There are other excellent resources about breathing - books, videos, articles - I just happen to like James Nestor.)", '@@VioletG43it’s a fantastic book! This is the shit. It may have saved my life. It has improved it immeasurably and helped me come to realise the sheer sickness of agricultural civilisations and the burden they impose on the individual.
This is amazing keep going😊

Been doing this practice for 3 months straight, I love it. So calming before I start work or to decompress after a long day or work out. I want to make a couple notes I made that someone may find useful.

1. Nose breathing really elevated this practice for me. I do nasal inhale and mouth exhale strictly now, it took a bit of time but I can do much longer breath holds now and have an overall better session. 

2. I do 40 breath reps instead of 30. I just scan the video back a bit after I hit 30 breaths. This also helps with holds and getting oxygen into your lungs.

3. Some days are easier then others. Practice really helps but some days are more difficult, don’t get discouraged. I also think it’s great to pro long the sessions if you’re feeling it. I like to usually do 4 to 5 full parts instead of 3 in this videos. Just like the breath reps I scan the video back after I complete to get in another one or two sections.

This method has been a game changer for my mood and productivity! Thanks Wim 🙏

comment: Thank You 💖⚛️

Hello all! So when I do this, I get severe ringing in my ears and I go very light headed, dizzy, my vision is blurry, and feel like I’m going to pass out or have a panic attack. I have had panic attacks before and I am quite apprehensive about triggering them again. Any advice because I feel like my reaction is quite extreme…thanks!
replies: ['As someone who had anxiety and recovered, you honestly need to learn to be ok with those feelings. Breathing exercises like these help to release dense energy that is dragging you down, making you anxious, depressed, etc. sometimes when that energy is released it moves through you and it “feels” like “anxiety” or a “panic attack” but it’s not. Just observe and trust your body and let it move through you and out of you. It’s the fear of your feelings that is giving the anxiety but feelings can’t hurt you, they’re just uncomfortable,so start to be ok with discomfort! It’s hard but it does get better and I hope the breathing is able to help you. also get lightheaded when I do this, it’s pretty normal. P', '@@permanentwavesmusic thank you so much.
