comment: BEWARE: Felt good for the first two weeks, but now I have tinnitus. Apparently a lot of people get tinnitus from doing this.
replies: ['You get tinitus because you overdo it, go step by step, let your feeling dictate when to stop, go easy first.\nYour body will adapt and you will become stronger.', '@@xNachoPG My point is there should be some sort of warning. He literally says, “If you want to pause for longer breath hold, do so now”. I am fully capable of doing so and can hold for over two minutes. What these videos don’t warn about is the potential of getting tinnitus. It’s quite prevalent. Just google the Wim Hoff Method with the word Tinnitus and see how large the number of people are that got it as a result. It’s a big problem. \nI’m not dumping on the method itself, because it is a great thing, but there aren’t any warnings or disclaimers and that really needs to change. I can’t do the exercise anymore because I could further damage my ears.', '\u200b@@Maikigaihe did give a warning lmao']

hi. i just started doing this a few days ago and i have a question about breathing to the more experienced people. after each round i feel something that i can describe as a sensation of vibration in the body and the more rounds i do the more it gets stronger and stronger. and if i do more then five rounds i also start to feel like the body starts to go numb and it is difficult or even almost impossible to move my fingers. so the question is - is that all normal reactions and what will happen if i will go on breathing after a numb state and is it safe?
replies:
['If you only started a few days ago maybe you are doing too much too soon. Stick with three rounds for now to let your body adjust.', 'As wim says, Get high on your own supply. As long as you feel okay, i think it’s fine, just don’t push too much. Good Luck', "here's what i've found out: the increasing vibration in the body / tingling sensation is a normal reaction in breathing techniques associated with hyperventilation. the numbness of the body is also a normal reaction in a longer sessions of such practices like holotropic breathwork. 

it is the result of decreased levels of carbon dioxide in the blood caused by hyperventilation. when the levels of CO2 in the blood drop, PH levels increase and become more alkaline. carbon dioxide acts as a vasodilator, meaning it keeps your veins open, so when your CO2 levels drop, your veins contract - which causes numbness and clamping sensations experienced in the hands. As CO2 aids the release of oxygen into your blood, your oxygen levels also lower. 

so my guess is: if to go on breathing after the numb state it may bring to the effects similar to holotropic. considering Wim's talk on DMT releasing."]

comment:
An important note to any anxiety sufferers like me (and anyone else who may be breathing wrong):
Even if your belly is expanding as you breathe, you may still be breathing shallowly. It's easy to move it without actually using the diaphragm. Your rib cage and lower back are also supposed to feel the breath and expand just a little. If it's been a while after last breathing properly, the sensation may even make you giggle. Of course, also try to make sure your throat doesn't tighten up.
replies: ['How is it possible to change a shallow breathing like that to a better and natural one including diaphragma?', '\u200b\u200b\u200b@@evanellemannambrosius823 i have no answer for your question but when babies were born they breath through their diaphragma , their chest going up and down not the belly.', '@evanelle: next time you breath you squeeze your belly button toward your spine instead of expand it out, you will feel that the air go down to your lower back and it is right', '@@ucNguyen-et2ym  should do that during inhalation?', '@@evanellemannambrosius823 Try to breath thru your nose, but is okay to breath from mouth a little until you can get nasal passages opening. Try pursed lips if you are breathing thru mouth. On inhale Relax your belly and expand ribs, especially lower rib cage front back and sides. Use your hands to feel your ribs to see if they are moving. On exhale push out air by drawing in all around belly and drawing in ribs (front back sides). Exaggerate to find the feeling.']

I have one recommendation to try during Wim Hoff Breathing sessions. Breath through your nose while holding your mouth closed during the inhale and exhale phase. comment: All the love...all the power 😊
day 11

Would Wim Hof breathing help afib? (After 2 weeks of thinking and doing) It should as it helps with vascularozation and O2.
The best time for me is on a treadmill at a brisk walk. I could hold my breath barely 15 seconds. Now I'm up to 20 seconds easy. When I'm light headed, I put my feet on the sides and rest. After 2 weeks I can tell a difference. The cold showers help also.  According to Wim as I understand  him, the cold showers tone the vascular system. This makes it easier for the heart to pump blood through the body (very important if you have Afib). So the heart slows its beats per minute (very important if you have Afib). I've done the cold showers for about 2 weeks. I think I detect a slower heart rate. Challenging to tell with an Afib beat,  but I think it has slowed some.
I took a break and came back
 I am definitely holding my breath longer. From studying it seems I am copying workouts at Altitude, which, per Dr's,  increases red bone marrow (At my age 68, most of my marrow is yellow fat marrow). Per the Dr's, red bone marrow produces more stem cells. Good for old folls.
Thanks Wim👍

replies: ['Maybe you are pushing too much air out on the outbreath before the breath hold, try only blowing half as as much air out than the usual, and see how that feels.', 'You also might not be inhaling deeply enough during the breathing stage. It took me practice to be able to fully fill up my lungs on every breath and it was uncomfortable at first.', 'It could also very much be a mental thing. The more relaxed you are and the lower your heartrate is the longer you can hold your breath. During the exercise focus on your heartbeat or meditate, dont let your mind wander. Try to relaxed all muscles, especially between the shoulders and around your heart(including your heart). Each thought you have will raise your heartrate to a degree.', 'Wim has a beginner video that’s slower and with shorter breath holds. I did that one for a while before coming to this one. Do you shake after ?

I have a question for all you amazing people doing the breathing exercise everyday. 

I have been doing the Wim Hof method for going on about 2 years now, and I've only made it to 2:17 ONCE. And to be honest, I was distracted by Wim talking (on the app the first time), and wasn't thinking about how long it had been. That seems to be what pulls my brain back to thinking most of the time. (How long has it been?) It's a fraction of a second thought, but it snaps me back to trying to hit an imaginary mark, and therefore, thinking, about the times. And it messes with my state of, not thinking? Presence?  I don't know what to call it lol  My avg breath hold (retention) based on what the app says, is anywhere from 1:30-1:45. I usually get 2 minutes on round 3 almost every time. (The last round) Also, I'm doing the BREATHING before bed (3 rounds, 30 breaths) and in the morning. (3 rounds, 30 breaths) After experimenting with more rounds for a while & more breaths, That's what feels good to me. (No forcing) I've been doing it twice a day for about 6 months, but at least once a day for almost 2 years. I also take an ice bath EVERY DAY. In the morning after my breath work. For about a year now. I'm up to about 10 minutes every morning. 

The myriad of benefits I have come across are almost too long to list. I won't do it here, I'll spare you all lol 😆 this is already long as hell & I'm assuming you know most of them anyway. 

All that to say, I want to improve my holds/retention times. I wanna hit 3 minutes. But when my body starts to feel what I can only describe as immense pleasure & tingling during a hold, (about 1:30-2:00 in) it's almost as if fear, anxiety etc.. makes me inhale and I always feel like I could have done a little more. I'm afraid I'll pass out, and my brain, no matter what I do, goes into what I like to call, "INHALE NOW" mode. Like a subconscious, uncontrollable, state of panic, or fear, that I feel, if I kept going, I would be forcing it. As we all know Wim says "NO FORCING!"  But would I be? Really? Or is that a trick or the mind??? 

After all this time, I feel like it's finally time to get past it, and hit that 3 minute mark. ANY help or advice to improve the times is super appreciated, and I'm very grateful for your help. 

And if it's a lot to type out or anything like that, I'm down to have a voice conversation maybe on Instagram? I dunno. I'll leave it to you guys. Let me know. And thank you in advance for your time and help. 

And if anyone wants any other info before answering, I'd be happy to reply with whatever you want to know. 

Thank you all! 
All the love, all the power. ❤
replies: ["I'm sorry that I don't know the answer to your question. I just want to say that I appreciate your sharing your experience. Just a thought - we are all individuals and differently made so are all going to have different limits, not better or worse, just different. On Wins channel there are listed ways to contact him, maybe you could ask him direct.", "@@mlk1965 Its cool man. Thanks for taking the time to reply, it was a shot in the dark in the first place brother. Thank you again. Hopefully someone else will have something. I've been thinking about contacting Wim. Thanks for the encouragement, I think I'll write up an email...\n\nPeace, & gratitude man. 😁🙏", 'With each breath or each time you do this exercise try to focus on your body, even if that means paying less attention to the video. So it doesn’t matter where you get in the exercise the important thing is to get in tune with your body and yourself and understand the thoughts that come up without forcing them out, just letting them pass. Good Luck', '@@samimrad7710 Thank you for the insight dude. I appreciate it very much. 🙏😁', '@@franksixer No worries, hope it helped']

comment: Wow,respect to thise man,he really helped me with stress,if ur reading thise,thank you

An important note to any anxiety sufferers like me (and anyone else who may be breathing wrong):
Even if your belly is expanding as you breathe, you may still be breathing shallowly. It's easy to move it without actually using the diaphragm. Your rib cage and lower back are also supposed to feel the breath and expand just a little. If it's been a while after last breathing properly, the sensation may even make you giggle. Of course, also try to make sure your throat doesn't tighten up.
replies: ["This is good advice, let your breath extend your stomach don't do it yourself"]

comment:
It's not just to be relaxed.
It's to INDUCE Flow State as well, You can get meaning of life on your command by doing Wim Hof Method.
1) it's exhausting, so in usual situation like working and social interaction (outside of breathing session), You'd better off just getting satisfied with yourself, You can induce Flow on command, you could be very proud of it. This fact make you relaxed and focused on your life.
2)When you want to take massive risk Wim Hof Method tend to help you, supreme elation like Flow help you getting on some actions that require courage.
3) As far as I know, detail of this breathing method can be ignored, I think it depends on situation and your predisposition. I don't fully follow rules put out by Wim Hof and other people and still can get relaxed or can induce Flow. I follow the big part of rules, sequence of breathing. Fully in, and longer easier exhale X times, after X times, exhale and suffocate myself to the limit(or few steps away from actual limit, You MUST FEEL MASSIVE ANXIETY if you're healthy), and inhale, and stop breathing for relatively short period of time in comparison with limit of my hold time.

comment:
Lots of interesting comments here. I have to say something and have few questions 

- I have been doing swimming since 3+ months now. I used to have headaches almost every monday although not that serious. But since i started swimming, i have never seen headache again. Looks like my immunity has increased. 
- From the comments, it is clear that swimming is same as wim hof + cold showers because in swimming, you do alot of proper breathing and at the same time, you are in water(morning cold water) for almost an hour. So i can indirectly testify that wim hof + cold showers is an amazing combination.

My question to wim hof practitioners 

-has anyone fixed migraine with wim hof AND/OR cold showers?
- how cold should the water be to call it a cold shower?
replies: ['well, for the second question, in my opinion as long as you feel the urge to opt out or not get in the water means its cold enough. As you’re going against comfort and instincts. Goodluck', 'I get hormonal migraines despite this n cold showers n syryanamaskars😢', '\u200b']

comment: I have struggled with anxiety and what our society calls ‘ADHD’ for all of my life. After the first few days of doing this breathing and taking cold showers, my entire hormonal balance reset and for the first time ever, I experienced life in a regulated way - not too happy, not too sad…no matter the external stimulus. I always knew adhd wasn’t actually a disorder - it is a coping mechanism that some of us develop to deal with trauma in early childhood as a way of disconnecting from the damaging input. After over a month of doing the WHM, I experience emotional regulation almost all of the time no matter what. I have drastically lower anxiety levels, and I have even kicked a cold as it was starting to develop after 24 hours of travel with a slightly weakened immune system. 2 days of breathing and cold showers and no trace of the cold is left and I feel amazing. Big pharma does not want anyone doing this because it literally creates wellness, happiness, independence and freedom from drug dependency, which is terrible for their profits of course. @Wim, you are what the people of the world needed to get us through these challenging times and to be able to discern truth from the thousands and thousands of lies being told to us every day about our own health and our control over it. Every human being has the ability to overcome disease and we do not need pharmaceutical drugs to do it, you have proved it. The power is within…and always has been. This is what the yogis have always been telling us. This is why Buddhist monks can control their body temperature and heart rate as well. THIS is the truth of our existence as a species. From the bottom of my heart and I think everyone that has experienced what you have given us would agree…you have my eternal gratitude for sharing your love and this beautiful method with the world. Thank you so much!!! All the love…all the power.❤❤❤
So beautiful 🤍🤗💨

comment: Can I get some advise on correct breathing? Loving the exercise but I’m concerned my technique is incorrect.
replies: ['Follow the breath as advised in the guidance, but this is not written in stone. It’s a suggested pattern for breathing. I find inhaling through both the nose and mouth works best for me. And when I consistently followed the guided session, my body kind of did the whole exercise on auto pilot. It took about ten days, roughly, maybe less. And when I’m extra busy and forget to do the work for a couple of days, when I return to it, I’m back on track in a day. I’ve seen Wim himself say, on multiple occasions, that it doesn’t matter how you actually inhale or exhale, once you commit fully. Best of luck. I’ve just finished a session and feel great already. Take care', '@@kevinmaher9526 Lovely advice, thank you.', 'You are most welcome my friend. Consistency is key, I found. 💪']

comment: Gratitude.

I've been doing this for about 6 months now at least once a week. I think it's good to find your own personal alterations. I've noticed that I get really dizzy if I do the 1 minute hold for the first one, so I hold for 1:30. I also like to take a few Pranayama breaths in between each set to allow the lungs to relax. For the third breath I hold for 2 minutes. I also sit up in a meditation position for the breaths and lie down for the holds.
    The benefits I've noticed include an almost complete reduction in asthma symptoms, which were pretty minor to begin with. Better lung health while running, such as a higher threshold of breathlessness. And a slight increase in the ability to breathe through my nose. In addition to that, I noticed mood improvement and a quicker digestion immediately after. Better mental clarity and reduced anxiety. Additionally I found that these breaths can be used as a pre-oxigenation method for exercise.
Who is “I AM HERE EVERYDAY AT THE RIGHT MOMENTÖ”

A few months ago, I was able to perform the first round’s 60-second pause with no problems. Now, I’m lucky if I make it to 45 seconds. In order to make the 90 second rounds, I have to add 20 breaths in addition to the 30. Does anyone know what is happening? I”m grateful that I’m much more in tune with my body but I’m confused as everything has stayed the same (I do it first thing in the morning on an empty stomach).
replies: ['It may be because of your lung capacity or some other reason but I don’t really know 🫤', 'It happens to me. Some days are easier than others. For me I believe is a mental thing, when I get distracted while holding I last more.', 'It’s okay, it’s not about how long you hold it for or the number of breaths you take. The important thing is for you to focus on your body as you breath, and by doing so get in tune with it, so just relax and focus on your body.']

comment: In case you're wondering: this guided session has 3 rounds of 30 breaths, with retentions of 1 minute, 1:30 minutes and again 1:30 minutes. Wim also has a video with longer (40 breaths per round, breath hold up to 2:30 minute): https://youtu.be/g0Cu31O3ND0

comment: Experienced WHM breather here with a quick question. Recently I have been having sore neck and a heat bag on my neck provides great relief. I did my WHM today with the heat under my neck and it made me wonder if there is any reason that would not be recommended? I don't really get any of the "tingling" sensation in my neck area when doing WHM breathing but the hands/face/feet I do. Any input would be appreciated. Thanks
replies: ['I don’t think the heat bag would affect anything, but if you think that it’s getting in the way, try to do it without the bag and focus on your neck.', '@@samimrad7710 Thanks for reply. My biggest reason for wondering, is when I do WHM my body temp very noticeably lowers more each round. I figure the lower body temp/heart rate contributes to using less oxygen thus being able to breath hold longer. So I wonder if adding heat is somewhat counterproductive for that reason.', '@@oxykostis3153 i get what you are saying now, try it out and see for yourself (with the bag/without) and see if that affects it']

The Universe. Man. Wow. Simultaneously the most beautiful. And The ugliest thing I've ever seen. Truly Magnificent.
AWESOME breathing techniques💚💚💚

I practice this breathing exercise every day since I've discovered it. After doing it for a few months I can now achieve nearly a two minute hold on the second and third rounds. I challenge myself to try and go a few more seconds every time I do it. I've recommended it to all my close friends and family. Every time I tell people that it involves holding your breath for 90 seconds after a full exhale they don't believe it is possible. 

I've developed anxiety in the last few years that manifests physical symptoms in my heart, and I'll experience rapid or pounding heartbeats while I'm not doing anything physical. It's miserable and scary. Any time I'm feeling some of this anxiety, or can't seem to calm my heart rate even though I'm just sitting at my desk, I will do this breathing exercise. It helps every single time, without fail. I close my eyes while I do it, and just feel my body existing in the present moment. I still struggle with anxiety, and out of all the strategies I've tried using to fight it, this breathing has been the most helpful for calming myself in the moment.

Maybe someone out there can relate to this. I'm so glad I found this video, and will continue my attempts to share this wonderful experience with as many people as I can.
replies:
['Yes, me too.', 'you are not alone, i’ve been dealing with heart palpatations and skipping beats although i live a healthy life and am an athlete. doctors could not find any physical disorders and prescripted antidepressants. been using them for 3 months but even though they seemed to help, palpatations was not fully gone. i started doing wim hof breathing 2 weeks ago and i only feel my hearth beating maybe a total of 30 mins in the day. im so happy.', 'update after 6 days: i now discovered there is such thing called hearthphobia and my symptoms are really similar to it. as far as i understand it is caused by stress and anxiety. my symptoms are nearly gone as i learned this phobia. i admitted to myself that i was wrong about my feelings and accepted what my doctor told me. i’m super fine now. i recommend researching this term “hearthphobia” to those who have the symptoms', "I'm 65 yrs and had this since teenage yrs,,, my resting heart rate would jump to double for no reason then eventually go to normal just as quick. I've never been able to pinpoint the reason nor the fix. I've always kept reasonable health and fitness but it really drains me when it happens", "@@ovuncvurucu7000 Hey, just checking in about this old comment thread. I had my anxiety under control for a while but its been coming back recently, so I've been practicing this breathing method again and I just found this old comment. 

Have you still been experiencing the palpitations and skipping beats in your heart? Have you continued taking the antidepressants the doctors recommended? Have they helped?

My doctors have suggested various anxiety and antidepressant medication, but I am hesitant to start any of them because I've never taken prescriptions medications in my life.

I still have the palpitations and skipping beats, even though I am a very fit and active person. Over the summer I biked 10 miles a day about 4 times per week, and I lift weights 3-4 times per week. Despite being healthy I still hyper focus on my heartbeat, and feel it constantly throughout the day. 



Also I researched cardiophobia and that is definitely what I'm experiencing. It helps comfort me a little to know that its all in my head, and the doctors say I'm fine, but I still get anxious when my heart is beating too hard for no reason. 

Hope life is treating you well my friend."]

comment:
Thank You for bringing this to Us! 
There are many charlatans out there, claiming to know the truth when ultimately, they just lead one astry. There are very view legitimate short cuts, especially concerning fitness, health and well-being - I understand this is one of them!

Sure, You can dive into vast ocean of all the different yoga practises, but learning to swim in these strange tides and not drowning due to the overwhelming size of it was to big of challenge, at least for me. 

As always, as new system towards growth arose on the horizon of my consciousness, those age-old questions that a lot of other folks are also just too familiar with, in some way or another, started to become the usual distraction once more: 
- "How long do I need to do this, until it pays of?"
- "Isn't there a more effective method?"
- "Does it really work, at all?"
- "Are there even any real benefits and if so, how good is the return on investment?"

For fifeteen years, I've been suffering from day time fatigue, for which no medical reason could be found. I've tried everything. I've. Tried. Everything! 
Nothing of which seemed to help at all. Until I discovered, that Yoga had to offer a wee bit more than just an excuse to go daydrinking for bored, suburban wives, that is. 
Simple Asanas focused on the core (i.e. lungs) coupled with the Wim Hof Method did the trick. It may be a strange way to end a paragraph this abruptly, however it symbolises how experietially my problems vanished figuratively with the snap of a finger. 

Again, Thank You for sharing Your method with Us! 
With Your reissuing of fire breathing, sometimes I wonder: 
How many more people are now thanks to You able to become a beacon towards a (-n even) brighter future?

All the Love, all the Power! ❤

QUESTION: on the last set, do i fully in and out then hold, or fully in and hold??
replies: ['The final round is the same as the previous ones. This means you DO breathe in, then out, then hold AFTER EXHALATION…….. this is followed by one deep breath in that is held for 15 seconds, and once you’ve held your full-of-oxygen lungs for\n15 seconds you exhale the air and that completes that round……. You are now ready to begin the next round by inhaling……or to complete the BREATHWORK by allowing your breathing to return to normal and moving your fingers and your toes! 😍 🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉🎉❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤ HOPE THIS MIGHT HELP:)😄😄😄!!!!!']

comment:
This is the same method used to Restart a phone or a computer
.
breathing: 0:21
.
Closing all apps ,
 emptying all ram data ,
 clearing cache files,

Holding breath: 1:58
.
 letting the components cool down, and engage it's resting current flow, screen is off.
.
(a component never truly stops working until you pull out the plug or battery)

Full breath hold: 2:58
.
Basically turning on the device with the power button.
.
I don't think this action will fix any of your problems if you have "damaged components"
.
But I believe it will give your brain enough ram data storage to troubleshoot your problem,
.
And if your brain is capable of commanding a "cure" or commanding a function to work properly
 
( like opening an app with no lag or slow internet) 

then that's where the "healing" happens.
.

I would recommend to 
"fully charge your device" 
if you're going try this, 
.
meaning you should have a good night's sleep, be hydrated and have eaten nutrient dense meal a few hours before  so your body has what it needs while "troubleshooting"

comment:
30 breaths: on last one, fully in and let go (exhale), hold 1 minute or more. 
Take  a deep breath in, hold 15 secs, exhale. 
Back to 30 breaths, on last one fully in and let go, hold 1:30 (90secs) or more. 
Breath fully in, hold 15 secs, let go.
Repeat one more round, resume normal breathing. Done!
Thank u

I did this for the first now.
you got to know, I’m in a bad place mentally and emotionally right now. 

I was addicted to Cocaine for 8 Years and to stop me from Coke I did Oxy’s as well and you surely know how that ended, it lead my Cocaine Addiction right to another.

I was about to end my life because I couldnt handle that Pain and this suffering.

I couldn’t even cry anymore because my Body and my Mind became numb at that point, I couldn’t feel myself anymore. 

3 Months ago I decided to give it a last try and went to rehab.
Good News, I’m sober since that day but I’m struggling ever since to stay strong.




My Life is upside down, I can’t go to work because of the early stages where I’m right now in Therapy (I’m working in a big finance Company, so you know drugs are very welcome to keep you working 70hrs+)



Even though I’m doing the right thing, I’m absolutely stressed and insecure/unsure how my Life will ever be normal again 

Today, after the first Breathing Lesson, I felt something I haven’t felt for a long time, peace of mind. 

Right after that I began to cry uncontrollably, it almost felt like all of that Trauma and Sadness i’ve been holding for years ,bursting right out of my Body.




I know I still have a long way to go, but it’s the first time that I’m feeling ready for what’s coming. 


Thank you Wim❤

And for all the People who can relate, stay strong Brothers and Sisters. You are not alone, you can do it.
BELIEVE IN YOURSELF

Wim, just saw you on you tube .It’s great to have such control over the body.I am a 56 yr old female with autoimmune hypo thyroid condition and having hypertension last 2 years . replies: ['My advice to you is to consult a doctor about any worries of blood pressure. He can do tests for you. As for these exercises, the point of them is in fact to stress your body and become more resilient to stress overall, as you will strengthen your nervous system doing it, thus becoming more calm. There is a scientific basis in this, so its not quackery. Exposing yourself to cold also does a lot of things for your mind and body, and the breathing helps you cope with the stress of the cold, so its doubly beneficial. Hope  this helps.']

replies: ['There’s not a right or wrong method. Sucks to be u

There are 4 types of breathing exercises. # 3 is a circle breathing - for (riding the earths polarity)!  Your technique is close. Don't fill or empty the lungs all the way. Fill the lungs 80/90%, empty 80/90%. This prevents clinching when (Impaled) with the earths polarity, while meditation.  Try #4,...... (Hyperventilation) A short quick half a lungs breath in / No pause/ a full lungs breath out. Slight pause then repeat. This super oxygenates the brain and FORCES kundalini energy from the base of the spine upwards, which opens the pineal gland and forces the lungs and blood to remove double the carbon dioxide on the breath out. No bag,.. no passing out.
Great when dealing with pain and suffering. Kundalini activation can be deadly when (Emotions are powering Hyperventilation),... !(HART STOPPING)!  Have hyperventilated for two weeks straight before,.... twice, with a week reprieve in da middle.  Try three days-(Three days of darkness) This is Kriya yoga 101.  Bow onto you Sir, I Do Namaste.....

The state of mind has been tested (Courage, leaving comfort, fear management, anxiety blocking), better management of the unconscious

Able to manage strokes and their pain with the method, resists more easily to some cold. 

My learning difficulties I think double, more organization of the concentration, better management of the anxiety

Guaranteed effect

comment:
Wim Hof, from my whole heart, thank you so much for your guidance and sharing your wisdom. Your breathing exercises have helped me so much. Years ago I had eaten an edible that got me way too high, so high that I forgot how to breathe, and it scared me beyond comprehension. I haven’t quite been the same since, and I’ve been dealing with anxiety and trouble breathing every day. Then one day, I said this is enough, and I searched for answers and came across your videos. I thank the Lord for this, as it has changed my life. My anxiety is going away. I can now breathe and not be afraid of breathing. I do your guided breath work twice a day, and I’m so grateful. Every day I grow stronger and every day I feel that trauma being released and getting smaller. You are changing my life for the better and that’s something I almost gave up hope for so thank you so much. Wishing you and everyone who is reading this comment and doing the hard work of bettering yourself, a beautiful prosperous life. ❤

Edit: This comment isn’t me saying marijuana is evil. It’s just my personal experience. I support everyone who wants to use it and I believe it can be a beautiful experience. This lovely herb can be healing, it just didn’t work for me. Peace 💗

Expert and advanced knowledge and advice:

Here’s what everybody’s missing about the Wim Hof method which Wim discussed in his more beginner friendly video which is less popular than this one. The reason why everybody quits this and don’t do it anymore like me. The missing link. You’re all doing it wrong, forgetting to follow the basics. This breathing method and video is supposed to be hard to do and not easy, because this is what Wim used to conquer world recorlds, so this world class technique needs world class users too, to achieve its full potential’s benefits. So if you think or feel that this is too easy, slow, or calm for you, then you’re doing it wrong, as you’re supposed to be heated up and tired/dizzy doing this. You’re supposed to inhale ‘till you can’t anymore, or fully in, then just exhale normally or how your body would exhale by itself, while following the time or the orange circle blob enlarging. At the largest point means you’ve also already inhaled fully in, then out following the circle shortening. You can do this nose, mouth or both, it doesn’t matter, as evidence you can hear Wims breathing through his mouth while the guy in his pushup video did it in his nose. So in short, the desired effects from this, makes you tired and heated up.

After 1 year, and then some, of the method here are my results:

1.Nasal congestion is still uncomfortable but I can breath through my nostrils. Before, I was addicted to nasal spray for 4 years and it was the ONLY way I could breath. I can breath!

2. I haven't gotten since starting. No allergies, no colds, no debilitating sore throats. Before I would get sick with the seasons and when I would eat bad food. Though, I have gotten sick once. When I smoked half a pack of cigarettes in one night. No sickness except maybe lil bug in my throat for a night every season.

3. It has created a discipline in my life that's easy and beneficial. It has given me the ability to know I can do other things. 

4. It helps me manage my depression. It hasn't been a cure for me, and other factors play in , but I'm a lil happier after I do it.

5. My work capacity has greatly increased. I helped my friends move once and thats when I realized. I was completely outperforming the others guys. One was the dad of the friend and the other was her brother. Just seeing them sweat and heave to keep up was profound to me.

All in all I'm going another year to see what else I can do!
